title: What's the difference between points, arguments, and evidence? How much of each should an essay have? - Quora

response.answer_text: What's the difference between points, arguments, and evidence? How much of each should an essay have? Well, evidence is the objective facts. “Objective” in the sense that they’re observable, demonstrable - they’re there in reality for others to see, even if they may construe them differently, they’re substance and features can’t really be denied. “Argument” is a serious of connected statements intended to establish a logical proposition. It’s a case being made, so to speak. “Point” in this context, is what you mean by it or what you intend it to prove. “Point” is a bit less technical than the other two. “Point” could just be the upshot, what you’re getting at. Point could be a crux or just a gist. In any case - get to the point. Every argument you make had best have a point. Better still, its point should go to support your overall conclusion - why include that argument, otherwise? Every argument you make had best be founded in one of two ways. 1) you argue from a universally-known (or assumed) uncontroversial truth. Something no one would dispute, and then reason logically from there, step by step, each step the inevitable consequence of the one before. Or else, 2) you’d dang well better include some evidence for your basis. The evidence is what supports the argument. Shows you’re not just reasoning from thin air. The two are by no means mutually-exclusive. Even if you’ve got an undisputed truth to begin from, you may need to add in additional evidence to support the argument you want to make. Generally, you include only the arguments you need to to establish the conclusion you intend. Strongest best. Every argument should have a point, and - unless you’ve got a really unshakable premise for that argument - some supporting evidence as well. Even if only to illustrate your main point, those evidence-based arguments really help to put it over.

here’s an easy sentence to help: in order to get your point across, you have to use evidence to fuel your argument. it may sound a little confusing, so don’t worry! you’ll get the hang of it. disclaimer: i’m tackling this as a high-school perspective. college requirements may vary — this is for an 11th or 12th grade level literature writing. a point is the main tone / reasoning you’re writing. however, when it’s used broadly, points are basically the equivalent of arguments, except to a lesser degree. considering there’s remotely no difference, i’m going to exclude points and make it into a main point. a point would be similar to — in an essay about taylor swift — debate. your point would be the fact you’re trying to convince people something about taylor swift. hopefully that makes sense! arguments are mostly used in debate essays and i suggest only using it for that type. essays, similar to, entertaining or informational, shouldn’t have an argument because the ideal audience is not threatening what you’re writing. it should either be in a funny tone or a factual one. arguments would be similar to “taylor swift is an evolutionary singer.” evidence is what fuels arguments, but it can be used for informational essays as well as debate essays. evidence would be similar to “taylor swift is an evolutionary singer because of her — from big or small — more than 300 award wins.” if you were to use evidence in an informational essay, it would be similar to “taylor swift has won over 300 awards, which fueled the decisions from the music award industries to give her artist of the decade and woman of the decade”. to answer the latter, it depends on the essay. you should really have one point and one argument, with three - five pieces of evidence for a classic two-page MLA formatting essay. with debate, you can have one - two arguments, with three - five evidences. and finally, with entertainment, it should ideally be one ( + ) point(s) and however much ‘evidence’ you wish (which would just be things such as metaphors, foreshadowing, and personification). hope this helped c:
